title: 105_s425
content: The "Cost-of-Living Board Act of 1997" allows for cost-of-living adjustments under the Social Security Act. This includes determining inflation adjustments. The Cost-of-Living Board established under the Cost-of-Living Board Act of 1997 determines a single percentage increase or decrease in the cost-of-living each calendar year after 1996. If adopted, this percentage will be used for cost-of-living adjustments in the following calendar year instead of the Consumer Price Index. The Cost-of-Living Board can make modifications to the single percentage used for cost-of-living adjustments under certain conditions. If the Board fails to adopt a percentage change for a calendar year, any adjustments for the following year will not take effect. The Cost-of-Living Board submits an annual report to the President and Congress by November 1, detailing the agreed percentage adjustment and the Board's decision on its adoption. Any Board determination under subsection (a) or (b)(1)(B) is not subject to judicial review. The term 'cost-of-living adjustment' refers to adjustments based on the Consumer Price Index in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The Cost-of-Living Board submits an annual report detailing the agreed percentage adjustment and its decision on adoption. Board determinations are not subject to judicial review. Adjustments are based on the Consumer Price Index in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The Code includes Titles II, XVI, XVIII, and XIX, as well as any other Federal program. The Cost-of-Living Board submits an annual report detailing the agreed percentage adjustment based on the Consumer Price Index in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. Board determinations are not subject to judicial review. The Cost-of-Living Board, established with 5 members including the Chairman of the Federal Reserve and President's Council of Economic Advisers, with 3 members appointed by the President with Senate consent. The Cost-of-Living Board consists of 5 members, including experts in economics and individuals with relevant government experience. The President considers appointing former members of the President's Council of Economic Advisers, Treasury department officials, and the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System. The Cost-of-Living Board consists of 5 members, including experts in economics and individuals with relevant government experience. The President shall submit nominations for the Board members requiring Senate confirmation within 30 days of the enactment of the Cost of Living Board Act of 1997, and the Senate must vote on confirmation within 60 days of receiving the nominations. The Cost-of-Living Board consists of 5 members with expertise in economics and government experience. The President must nominate Board members for Senate confirmation within 30 days of the Act's enactment. Board members serve 5-year terms, with initial appointments staggered at 1, 3, and 5 years. Vacancies on the Board are filled in the same manner as the original appointment. The Cost-of-Living Board consists of 5 members appointed by the President with expertise in economics and government experience. Vacancies on the Board are filled in the same manner as the original appointment, with individuals chosen to fill a vacancy appointed for the unexpired term of the member replaced. The term of any member appointed shall not expire before the date on which the member's successor takes office. The Board must hold its first meeting within 30 days of all members being appointed, with subsequent meetings determined by majority vote. The Cost-of-Living Board consists of 5 members appointed by the President with expertise in economics and government experience. The Board may close meetings by majority vote, make records available to the public, and require a majority for a quorum. A Chairperson and Vice Chairperson are selected from the appointed members. The Board has the power to hold hearings. The Cost-of-Living Board, appointed by the President, has the authority to hold hearings, gather information from federal agencies, and use postal services as needed to fulfill its objectives. The Board appointed by the President can accept gifts or donations and compensates members for their services, with non-government members receiving a daily rate equivalent to level III of the Executive Schedule. The Board members are allowed travel expenses and per diem while performing services, and the Chairperson can appoint an executive director and additional staff without following civil service laws. The Chairperson of the Board has the authority to set compensation for the executive director and staff without following certain federal pay regulations. Federal government employees can be detailed to the Board without additional reimbursement. The Chairperson of the Board can set compensation for the executive director and staff without following federal pay regulations. The Board may procure temporary services at specified rates, and termination rules under the Federal Advisory Committee Act do not apply. Appropriations are authorized for the Board's purposes.
